Summary: SeaMonkey (Mac) update version 2.49.5 made it impossible to edit old webpages!
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_15_2) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/13.0.4 Safari/605.1.15

Steps to reproduce:

I was editing old webpages, just changing the wording in some text.. 


Actual results:

My page backgrounds disappeared and the placement of graphics was way off. I wasted 2 hours, doing everything carefully and testing my results step by step, but it was impossible to get things right. 

I had to go back to SeaMonkey version 2.49.4 in order to keep my page backgrounds and the placement of graphics. I wasted 2 hours today with version x.5 until I finally restored version x.4, and then everything went smoothly. 


Expected results:

I should have been able to edit the text and then upload the edited webpages to my website. But even pages that looked almost OK in SeaMonkey did not look OK in Safari and Chrome. Once I restored the older x.4 version, everything worked as it always has. I love SeaMonkey because of how simple it usually is!

(But I wish I could open composer and drag files into it instead of having to browse for them.)

Summary: rss folder management buggy
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/79.0.3945.94 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce:

I subscribed to RSS feeds and managed them in folders.


Actual results:

The folder management is very confusing. Sometimes one feed gets splitted into a folder and messages part which will not end up in the same folder.
Sometimes the feed is recieved in the main folder while displayed in the subfolder. You also will need a restart in order to get things displayed properly in the feed subscriptions.

I attached an example (where feed names where shortened due to privacy reasons). You see that the matrixorg feed appears twice in the subscription list alhough it was subscribed once. You also don't see it twice in the main window, but you might have odd results like recieving new messages in the wrong folder.

This might be related to a 15 year old bug, which I also experienced:
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=296264


Expected results:

There sould just be one object that can be moved easily between the folders.

Summary: Install upgrade attempt result in endless reboot requirement and no functioning browser
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:65.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/65.0

Steps to reproduce:

Ran seamonkey-2.57a1pre.en-US.win64.installer.exe for build 20200114043003.
Forgot to close all running Seamonkey windows first.


Actual results:

The installer required a system reboot to complete the install.
I rebooted the computer.
On reboot, the Seamonkey icon had a different graphic and, on clicking on it, a messagebox popped up saying I needed to reboot to complete the installation.
The same messagebox popped up on my running the installer program, above, again.
Rebooted the system again.
Same situation.
Rebooted the system again.
Same situation.
Deleted all files and directories from C:\Users\...\AppData\Local\Seamonkey, where the Seamonkey application is.
Ran the installer again.
The installer went farther this time and didn't request a reboot, but said, "You don't have sufficient disk space to install to this location."  (There is 245GB of free space.)
Looked in AppData\Local again;  the Seamonkey directory, which I hadn't deleted, was now gone.
Ran the installer again.
Seamonkey installed correctly and works fine.

If it is true that the installer required a reboot because the program was running, that's insane.
If it is true that the installer required a reboot because the program was running, why didn't it give the user a chance to fix the situation before requiring a reboot?
If it is true that the installer required a reboot because the program was running, why would it continue to require a reboot when the program wasn't running, no matter whether or not the reboot finished whatever was to be finished?

The disk space issue seems to be the same as:
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1215786

I found other bugs, 12, 18, 20 year old, for the installer component that mention the word, "reboot."  A few are:
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=360897
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=138840
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=110882
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=119530
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=43792
I have another program, I forget which, which won't run because it thinks my Windows version is too old; turns out it's because I have disabled some Windows Service, I forget which.
Perhaps the installer also thinks my Windows version is old.
I am running Windows 10, 1803.


Expected results:

Install.

Summary: Element.scrollIntoView does not follow spec handling "null", "{}" input arguments
Don't always update lastRelatedTab information when browser.tabs.insertAllTabsAfterCurrent is true
Description: Bug 1353428 add a pref for opening all new tabs after the current tab. lastRelatedTab information should not be updated when the current tab is not related.

Summary: download manager backend not initilaized if SeaMonkey is not started as normal browser (non private navigator) first
Description:
The sessionstore-windows-restored notification is not send if you start SeaMonkey with the private flag or with another component like mail/news. This means that the code in this._onBrowserStartup(subject) in nsSuiteGlue.js is not run initially. This wasn't much of a problem previously but now the jsdownloads backend is initialised here among other things. Currently this results in the download names not shown if you open it. Also the progress dialog is not shown. The taskbar is also not intialised. 

Workaround: As soon as you open a normal browser window the notification is send and the init code executed.

Not sure what the best solution is. Firefox sends the notification if only a private window is opened but our seession store is more or less different and outdated. Send it with a null window like in Fx also results in the notfication not shown (see Bug 573384) and if we have only a address book or mailnews window the startup code will like fail to show a notification too.

So probably best do move some components out of _onBrowserStartup and into a delayed startup like in Firefox after final-ui-startup is received.

I am not sure if we can fix it for 2.53.1 but if not the workaround should be put into the release notes.

Summary: Disable startup cache in SeaMonkey 2.53 and 2.57 build config.
Description:
The startup cache causes problems with enabling and disabling extensions and themes in 2.53.1 and up. Initial findings suggest that any performance gain here is neglectable so it should be disabled by default. 
This can be done by providing --disable-startupcache as an option in the mozconfig file but we probably want it by default so that distributions don't need to do it too.

See:
Bug 1444957
Bug 1484393
http://forums.mozillazine.org/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=3058711&p=14856248#p14856248

Summary: Severe memory usage
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.1 Lightning/5.8.1

Steps to reproduce:

Just had to browse the internet, on any given day, any given time.

I could have only one site open, or 4 tabs or more and it could end up all the same - getting so slow and waiting for clicks on links to happen or pages to scroll, etc.


Actual results:

It seems eventually Seamonkey starts to eat RAM. I'm not sure when or how, as it seems to happen randomly and no specific websites.

One minute things are going just fine, the next thing I know I'm waiting for the cursor to change when hovering on a link or waiting for the page to scroll, etc. The delays in things to happen usually are a couple seconds but no more than three seconds so far, but the delay in *every* thing I want to do, not just surfing, but doing anything on my computer, has that short delay anytime I want to do anything.

When I open ksysguard to see what might be the problem app, it's Seamonkey using 2+ GB of RAM (of my 12GB).

If I close Seamonkey and open/use Firefox (for instance) and go to the same sites I was just on, with the same number of tabs of the same sites, nothing is going wrong and ksysguard shows it only using around 190MB of RAM, so this was my non-scientific, simpleton test, heh.


Expected results:

Nothing other than just continue to not have the sudden delays for anything to happen on my computer when it suddenly starts to eat RAM.

This is Seamonkey 2.53.1b1

Summary: Can't check out SeaMonkey 2.53.1 source
Description:
According to the README at <https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/seamonkey/releases/2.53.1/README.txt> linked to from the SeaMonkey 2.53.1 release page at <https://www.seamonkey-project.org/releases/2.53.1>, the instructions for pulling the code from the source repository begin as follows:

hg clone -r SeaMonkey_2_53_1_RELEASE https://hg.mozilla.org/releases/comm-esr56

This is a non-starter, because no such repository exists:

$ hg clone -r SeaMonkey_2_53_1_RELEASE https://hg.mozilla.org/releases/comm-esr56
abort: HTTP Error 404: Not Found

I poked around <https://hg.mozilla.org/releases/> but didn't see any *-esr56 repositories, nor do I see a SeaMonkey_2_53_1_RELEASE tag in any of the other repositories.

It would be great if this issue could be rectified as it's preventing us at openSUSE from efficiently packaging the new release.

Summary: SeaMonkey 2.53.1 source release tarball is huge because it includes a Git repository
Description: The source release tarball for SeaMonkey 2.53.1 at <https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/seamonkey/releases/2.53.1/source/seamonkey-2.53.1.source.tar.xz> includes a full Git repository in the directory seamonkey-2.53.1/.git, and as a result the size of the tarball is more than three times bigger than the source release tarball for 2.49.5 (755 MB vs. 232 MB).  I am assuming that this is an error in the packaging.

Summary: Source code checkout README should be served as text/plain
Description:
The various SeaMonkey release pages (e.g., <https://www.seamonkey-project.org/releases/2.53.1>) link to a README.txt (e.g., <https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/seamonkey/releases/2.53.1/README.txt>) with instructions on how to fetch the source code.  This README.txt is always served with the MIME type binary/octet-stream -- see below for sample output from wget.  Serving the file this way means that web browsers (including SeaMonkey itself) generally refuse to display the file, instead forcing the users to download it.  This is rather annoying; it would be nice if the file were instead served with the MIME type text/plain.

$ wget -S https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/seamonkey/releases/2.53.1/README.txt
--2020-03-02 13:16:31--  https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/seamonkey/releases/2.53.1/README.txt
Resolving archive.mozilla.org (archive.mozilla.org)... 99.86.243.6, 99.86.243.105, 99.86.243.88, ...
Connecting to archive.mozilla.org (archive.mozilla.org)|99.86.243.6|:443... connected.

Summary: Fix popup notification in modern theme

Summary: Elf-hack errors prevent compilation of SeaMonkey 2.53.1
Description:
When building SeaMonkey 2.53.1 on openSUSE Tumbleweed, I am getting errors that advise me to use `--disable-elf-hack` and to file a bug:

```
===
=== If you get failures below, please file a bug describing the error
=== and your environment (compiler and linker versions), and
=== provide the pre-elfhacked library as an attachment.
=== Use --disable-elf-hack until this is fixed.
===
# Fail if the library doesn't have INIT_ARRAY .dynamic info
readelf -d test-array.so | grep '(INIT_ARRAY)'
 0x0000000000000019 (INIT_ARRAY)         0x9df0
/home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/seamonkey/obj-x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/build/unix/elfhack/elfhack -b -f test-array.so
test-array.so: Reduced by 16184 bytes
# Fail if the backup file doesn't exist
[ -f 'test-array.so.bak' ]
# Fail if the new library doesn't contain less relocations
[ $(objdump -R test-array.so.bak | wc -l) -gt $(objdump -R test-array.so | wc -l) ]
===
=== If you get failures below, please file a bug describing the error
=== and your environment (compiler and linker versions), and
=== provide the pre-elfhacked library as an attachment.
=== Use --disable-elf-hack until this is fixed.
===
# Fail if the library doesn't have INIT .dynamic info
readelf -d test-ctors.so | grep '(INIT)'
make[4]: *** [Makefile:25: test-ctors.so] Error 1
```

The problems indeed go away when I use `--disable-elf-hack`.  Perhaps they arose as a result of the decision in Bug 1381211 to remove this flag.

Attached are (what I hope are) the pre-elfhacked libraries. (It would have been nice if the error messages were a little clearer about what files to attach.)

Compiler: GCC 9.2.1 20200128 [revision 83f65674e78d97d27537361de1a9d74067ff228d]
Linker: ln (GNU coreutils) 8.31

Summary: Checksum errors for SeaMonkey 2.53.1 release
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:52.0) Gecko/20100101 SeaMonkey/2.49.5

Steps to reproduce:

There seem to be a few issues with the checksum files (MD5SUMS.txt, SHA1SUMS.txt, SHA512SUMS.txt) at <https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/seamonkey/releases/2.53.1/>:

* The checksums for <source/seamonkey-2.53.1.source.tar.xz> are incorrect in all 3 files. Correct checksums are included in <source/seamonkey-2.53.1.checksums> (in the source/ subdirectory).
* Paths for language-specific builds are messed up, e.g. <platform/win32/en-US/cs/de/en-GB/seamonkey-2.53.1.en-GB.win32.zip should be just platform/win32/en-GB/seamonkey-2.53.1.en-GB.win32.zip> (without the <en-US/cs/de/> part) - each subsequent language has all previous languages in its path, even though they're not actually organised that way on the server.

Not so problematic, but presumably the paths should match organisation on the server:
* Paths for executable builds have <platform/> prefixed (e.g. <platform/win32/...> should presumably be just <win32/...>)
* Paths for updates have <tmp/releases/2.53.1/> (e.g. <tmp/releases/2.53.1/update/win32/...> should presumably be just <update/win32/...>)


Actual results:

* Checksums for the file downloaded from <https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/seamonkey/releases/2.53.1/source/seamonkey-2.53.1.source.tar.xz> don't match those specified in MD5SUMS.txt, SHA1SUMS.txt and SHA512SUMS.txt
* File paths in MD5SUMS.txt, SHA1SUMS.txt, SHA512SUMS.txt do not match the paths to the files on the server


Expected results:

* Checksums for the file downloaded from <https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/seamonkey/releases/2.53.1/source/seamonkey-2.53.1.source.tar.xz> should match those specified in MD5SUMS.txt, SHA1SUMS.txt and SHA512SUMS.txt
* File paths in MD5SUMS.txt, SHA1SUMS.txt, SHA512SUMS.txt should (presumably) match the paths to the files on the server

Download should finish.

Summary: Seamonkey 2.53.1 installer is not digitally signed
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.1

Steps to reproduce:

Download and run SeaMonkey 2.53.1 installer on Windows 10 64-bit


Actual results:

Cylance blocked it during download
Waived the installer in Cylance
Windows won't elevate an unsigned executable, so still fails
Elevation block is not Windows default behavior, but likely to be enforced by group policy in an enterprise environment. Lack of digital signature may contribute to Cylance quarantining the installer.  I was able to work around both blocks at work; no problems at home where the system is less locked down.


Expected results:

New version gets installed

Summary: In the newest update, it is impossible to save a file with a different filename, including changing the filename to another file that already exists.
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:74.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/74.0

Steps to reproduce:

Edited a page as a template for a new page.  Selected "Save As" to change to the new desired filename (and preserve the "old" filename for the page used as an editing template).  New filename also already existed as a placeholder.  Selected that filename, and when prompted whether I wanted to replace the existing file with the "new" filename, I answered "yes."


Actual results:

The changes to the "template" file saved using the OLD filename, and the file under the old name reflected the new changes.  The file under the desired filename was not changed.  It was impossible to change the filename using "Save As."


Expected results:

The edited file should have saved as the new filename and replaced the existing placeholder file under that filename.  Instead, the edited file was saved with the OLD filename.

Summary: Fix context menu for BiDi
Description: Bug 1578062 introduced a regression in using gBidiUI rather than gShowBiDi in some parts of the context menu code.

Summary: Partially reverse patch to scrollbar css for SeaMonkey
Description:
It seems the patch no more needed now. At least the part related to classic theme.

Currently, with classic theme there is just a rectangle instead of the floating button in the scrollbar. This annoys Linux users who prefer to use the same theme as in the other desktop applications.

Fortunately, when I revert the classic-related changes, all looks fine. Scrollbar looks like in other apps (as before the switch to gtk3).
Probably something is changed since 2.49.5 time, and now things work properly.

Note, that there are some gtk3 themes (ie. Adwaita), which do not use scrollbar top/bottom buttons at all. It is the theme feature, and it is intended to be -- ie. not SM only, but all the desktop apps have no such buttons.

Summary: When I try to open email Compose from command line, 'from=' option is ignored
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.1 Lightning/5.8.1

Steps to reproduce:

I have several email accounts on SeaMonkey Mail client.
From command line (linux) I want to open a new composer window with "From" field being one specific email (ex.: myemail5@example.com) of my accounts. I run the command:

seamonkey -compose "from='myemail5@example.com',to='to email <toemail@example.com>',subject='the subject',body='the body'"


Actual results:

Composer window opens with filled  "to", "subject" and "body" as provided in command line.  For "from" it uses my first added email account. Any other tries I did (using only from as option/ using the email/ using the email with my name)   , from is ignored. This was also happening in SeaMonkey 2.48 / 2.49


Expected results:

It should have use the "from" email, as command " seamonkey --help " suggests. 

Just now, as I was going to submit the bug, I discovered this bug:

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=630804#c2

which mentions the option "preselectid="  which isn't shown in the --help output. I tried all numbers from 1 to 10 without success. I wrote " about:config " in the address bar, and searched for my email. I got several lines, but from line with "Preference Name" mail.identity.id5.useremail, I got "id5"  and I did my command as: 

seamonkey -compose "preselectid=id5,to='to email <toemail@example.com>',subject='the subject',body='the body'"

From is still ignored, but this trick did the job.

Two suggestions: 
1) update of --help message to show "preselectid" option.
2) support of from, as I saw that works for thunderbird.

Summary: SeaMonkey consumes 100% CPU
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.1 Lightning/5.8.1

Steps to reproduce:

Every once in a while, the browser starts consuming 100% CPU
(100% of one core, to be exact, see the screenshot - 25% of my 4 core CPU).
This started happening after upgrading to 2.53.1, it never happened
in the previous version (2.49.5). All versions are 32-bit running
on 32-bit Windows 7.

The steps to reproduce this are vague, I know, but there seems
to be a pattern. As far as I can tell, it is related to memory
and the garbage collector going on some sort of an infinite loop.
When this happens, the browser is essentially not usable, but
is working although with VERY VERY slow response to scrolling,
closing/switching tabs etc.

The pattern I observed:

* The "age" of the browser matters.

This seems to be related to how long the browser has been running.
I have never seen it in a freshly open browser. Instead, it usually happens
at the end of the day when I have been using it for the entire day.

* The number of tabs does not seem to matter

I have seen this happen with just a few tabs. At the time I captured
the attached logs, I had only 2 tabs open. However, the number of tabs
does seem to make it easier for this bug to happen. The most common
pattern - open a web site (I usually do this with a news website,
http://www.lenta.ru), then Ctrl+Shift+Click on multiple new articles
so that they are open in background tabs without switching to them.
Having said that, even opening 20-40 tabs does not trigger this reliably.
The critical part, I think, is how many tabs are being open at the same time,
not how many tabs are actually open in a "complete" state.

* The actual URL does not matter

Most commonly I see this on http://www.lenta.ru, but I suspect this
is just because of my browsing pattern. I have seen this happen
with other sites too. What is interesting is that even when the browser
gets into this "loop" state, if I kill the browser in the Task Manager
and restart it, when the browser restarts and opens all the same tabs
again, everything is working.

Bottom line - this seems to be a race condition of sorts somewhere
in the memory allocation or garbage collection. It is not a concrete
error on any one concrete page.

* Closing all tabs stops the loop

If I am patient enough and close all tabs, the browser becomes
responsive again. The attached logs were captured after closing
all tabs after getting into this "loop" state without restarting
the browser.

Unfortunately, this is as much information as I can gather.
This happens almost every day to me, but I do not have a very reliable
way to reproduce this. I am attaching concise and verbose memory
logs here. Please let me know if there is anything else I can capture,
preferably from the outside of the browser as getting it done
inside takes forever.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Visit https://zapier.com/demo
2. Click the play button on the embedded video


Actual results:

The embedded video is not playing


Expected results:

Should play the embedded video.

Firefox has no problem play the video on the page.

Summary: customization of toolbars in Composer and formatting toolbar in MailNews Composition allows moving buttons around
Description:
+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #606683 +++

In Bug 606683 both Composer toolbars were made customizable. It is now possible to move a button from the formatting toolbar into the general toolbar and vice versa. Depending on the status of the main window the new buttons are either not hidden or are hidden together with the toolbar.
Auto Enable/Disable of the items seems to work. 
Possible fix might be to not autohide/show the formatting toolbar.

Summary: Fix globalmessagemanager following landing of Bug 888600
Description: In Bug 888600 ContentFrameMessageManager was moved to WebIDL, we need to fix our one use of globalmessagemanager in nsSuiteGlue.js (see part 6 of bug - https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/243246b2f440)

Summary: help_help.xhtml ("Using the Help Window"): location of findbar and print button need to be updated
Description: In SeaMonkey Help, the "Using the Help Window" page says that the Ctrl/Cmd+F search bar "will open at the bottom" and that the print button is "near the top-right corner of the Help window", but these now appear near the top and top-left, respectively.

Summary: [Mac] Open Help shortcut lacks modifier
Description:
Bug 1611714 removed our platform-specific overlays. In the Mac version we had:
    <key id="key_openHelp"
         key="&openHelpCmd.key;"
         modifiers="&openHelpCmd.modifiers;"
         command="cmd_openHelp"/>

It looks like the modifiers part got lost.  The shortcut for open Help is now "?" instead of "Cmd+?" which is weird :-).

Summary: Nearby blank page shown instead of monorail issue listing
Description:
### Steps how to reproduce   
with installation of unofficial (by wg9s) De SeaMonkey 2.53.3beta 1 pre Mozilla/5.0  (NT 6.1; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 Build 20200510220906 (Default Classic Theme, newly created User Profile) on German WIN7 64bit:


1. Visit [monorail issue list](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list) for search results  
   ¬ª Chromium Bug tracking pare appears   
     Expected: long list   
     Actual: only some kind of Heading menu appears, but no list  üò•

### Additional information
a) Old UI also does not work, you try with a click on "[View in the old UI](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list_old)" 
b) Works fine with FF 76.0.1 (64-bit), Chromium Version 85.0.4161.0
c) No obvious [DUPs](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/buglist.cgi?longdesc_type=allwordssubstr&product=SeaMonkey&chfieldfrom=2020-01-01&classification=Client%20Software&list_id=15271189&v1=white%20blank%20empty&query_format=advanced&o1=anywordssubstr&chfield=[Bug%20creation]&longdesc=page&f1=longdesc) found   
d) Switching to FF User Agent does not help
e) Error Console shows several warnings most interesting might be  

- Zeitstempel: 30.05.2020, 18:43:32 
- Warnung: Laden fehlgeschlagen f√ºr das <script> mit der Quelle "https://storage.googleapis.com/crdx-feedback.appspot.com/feedback.js".
- Quelldatei: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list
- Zeile: 1

Summary: Give a non-localised version of DDG to all locales
Description: Localised versions of DDG override any setting user may have configured for region so, we should also ship a non-localised version in the list of available search engines.

Summary: Request for camera & microphone access
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.2

Steps to reproduce:

Go to my Facebook messages page. Press video chat button. 


Actual results:

The screen Request for Camera & Microphone access says: An Error occured when trying to get access to Camera and/or Microphone:
<![EX[["Minified invariant #14422; %s TAAL[2]",""]]]>
Also Google Meet via SeaMonkey browser hangs up. To my opinion, for a similar reason.


Expected results:

No problem with same Facebook links in Edge, in stand-alone Messenger application, in Zoom, in Google Meet via Edge.

Summary: pt-BR SeaMonkey help: remove &copyright.string;
Description:
Help files in the pt-BR Seamonkey lang pack still have "

©right.string;

", which is not defined (removed in bug 551742?), leading to XML parsing errors. Steps to reproduce: open the help viewer in pt-BR. This should display an "undefined entity" error message for welcome_help.xhtml.

Summary: PNG images on particular web page shown vertically squished
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.2

Steps to reproduce:

Visited Canon website page about new R5 model at:
https://www.usa.canon.com/internet/portal/us/home/explore/product-showcases/cameras-and-lenses/eos-r5


Actual results:

The large picture of the new camera appeared squished vertically.


Expected results:

The new camera picture should rendered correctly, which Firefox and Edge do.

Summary: Default for charPrefs should be a char not null
Description:
When passing a default pref through to Services.prefs.getCharPref it should be a char and not null.
When Bug 1428401 switched from getPref helpers, which were more tollerant, it did not fix this.

Summary: New mail message notification blank pop-up
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:76.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/76.0

Steps to reproduce:

1)I had opened as usual Seamonkey and new messages has downloaded first with proper notification in Windows 10 x64 (1909 up-to-date)
2) After time another automatic pop3 get mail event has occured and small notification has pop-uped but blank - phisicaly no new messages arrived to inbox. This pop-up is much shorter in time than that when real messages was arriving.
3) After next automatic pop3 email get event - the same ( fast blank popup).
No use any spam filtering anywhere and nothing changed in settings. It has never happened before. I couldn't screenshot this because it lasted too short but annoying.



Expected results:

No messages arrived, no pop-ups.

Summary: [SM] Tough autocomplete when entering mail address enforces existing address vs. user-typed address
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/81.0.4044.123 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce:

I tried to compose a new mail to huber@mail.invalid


Actual results:

Since there was already a mail contact like karl.huber@mail.invalid in some prior conversation, Seamonkey always suggested this one and even replaced "huber@mail.invalid" with "karl.hber@mail.invalid" when pressing the enter key. This even happened when deleting the auto suggestion (by pressing del) and pressing enter afterwards.
I had to type <huber@mail.invalid> to manage to send to that one.

Not that in a big company there are often people with the same surnames or similar names. So this behaviour is quite unhandy and can lead to mailing wrong people by mistake.


Expected results:

Thunderbird 68.9 will keep "huber@mail.invalid" if you delete the auto suggestions, which can be a way to handle this.
However, Seamonkey should not ignore if you don't want to use the contact of the auto suggestion.

Summary: Won't play videos at many popular websites, Opera can play them?
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.2

Steps to reproduce:

Clicked to play a video in SeaMonkey. Many site videos fail to open or play on many popular sites. Just get a blank box. Opera can play with no problems. Also scrolling/lockup issues. Try scrolling on sites like Amazon browsing history or Home Depot. Very slow or freezes the 64-Bit browser under Windows 10 64-Bit. See example, sorry bad lanquage: https://therightscoop.com/watch-man-threatens-to-up-a-bunch-of-nypd-officers-it-doesnt-go-well-for-him/


Actual results:

Will not play video links on many websites. You get a blank box. See example link above. Many Vimeo videos fail to play. YouTube videos play okay.

Browsing my Amazon browsing history of items previously viewed, causes SeaMonkey v2.53.2 to freeze, crash, or stall. Home Depot is similarly very slow to scroll up or down.


Expected results:

I am not seeing these issues in Opera or MS Edge. Don't use Chrome, due to privacy tracking issues. Is there an Add-On or Extension that SeaMonkey needs installed to play common website videos?

Summary: Lightning 5.8.2 - Today pane: Wrong day of week displayed on startup
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 SeaMonkey/2.53.2

Steps to reproduce:

SeaMonkey 2.53.2 / Lightning 5.8.2

Start SeaMonkey, then open the Mail & News component
At the top of the "Today Pane", the correct date is shown, but with the wrong day of the week. For example:
* Yesterday (Wed 24 June 2020), it was showing the day as "Mon"
* Today (Thu 25 June 2020), it is showing the day as "Tue"
* Another user on the SeaMonkey users' mailing list reported that on Tue 23 June 2020 is was showing the day as "Mon" for them.

Clicking the "Go to Today" button changes the display to the correct day of week. Clicking "One Day Forward" and then "One Day Backward" to return to the current day changes the display to the correct day of week.

The same still happens with a new profile.

Summary: Exporting SeaMonkey v2.53.3's addressbook does not contain all datas.
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.3

Steps to reproduce:

1. Make a SeaMonkey (SM) v2.53.3's address book's contact with most/all datas filled out like addresses (home especially), phone numbers, etc.
2. Export this address book into a VCF file from its Tools menu.
3. View this VCF file in a text editor or import into a program that can VCFs.


Actual results:

Inside the exported VCF, it is missing datas as shown in SM's address book. For an example with my test:
begin:vcard
fn:ant dude
n:dude;ant
org:;a dept
adr:;;1234 address;some city;ca;12345;usa
email;internet:ant@farm.edu
title:worker
note:some notes
url:http://work.edu
version:2.1
end:vcard

I have a home address. Why was it not exported correctly?


Expected results:

SeaMonkey's address book's export should exported all datas.

Thunderbird v78.0.1's address book's export to VCF files had no problems when it migrated my abook.mab into abook.sqlite file when I tested it. It seems like SeaMonkey has an export VCF bug. I was able to reproduce this in updated mac OS Mojave v10.14.6 and Debian Jessie v8 machines too.

Summary: http and https serve different versions of the website
Description:
Currently <http://seamonkey-project.org/> is serving significantly different content than <https://seamonkey-project.org/>.  The site served by HTTPS was last modified on July 12, 2020; it offers SeaMonkey 2.53.3.  The site served by HTTP was last modified on February 27, 2020 and offers SeaMonkey 2.53.1.

Please synchronize the content of the two sites, or ensure that HTTP is automatically redirected to HTTPS.

Summary: Poor rendering of pages on GitHub
Description:
SeaMonkey 2.53.3 has problems rendering certain pages and page elements on GitHub.  The problems did not occur when I was using SeaMonkey 2.53.2 (though I suppose it is possible that GitHub updated its UI at about the same time that 2.53.3 was released).

Examples of rendering problems:

1. Most of the issue search results page are completely scrambled.  See <https://github.com/logological/gpp/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+master> as an example.  The attached screenshots show the problematic rendering in SeaMonkey 2.53.2 and correct rendering in Firefox 78.0.2.

2. On any GitHub form that allows you to enter Markdown and to preview it in a separate tab, the preview tab always shows an "Error rendering preview" message.  See <https://github.com/logological/gpp/issues/new> for an example (but note that this page can be viewed only if you are logged into a GitHub account).  The attached screenshots show the problematic rendering in SeaMonkey 2.53.2 and correct rendering in Firefox 78.0.2.

Summary: Expose intl.locale.matchOS in the UI in SeaMonkey
Description:
The "intl.locale.matchOS" preference still does not mentioned anywhere in UI, but is widely used at downstream level.
It can confuse downstream users, since the existing UI still offers the manual choice, whereas this choice has no effect (if the preference is set).

Due to technical policies, Linux and UNIX distros should provide all the langpacks in their packages. The choice of language is determined at runtime by environment variables (LC_MESSAGES, or LC_ALL, or LANG). Thus "intl.locale.matchOS" is normally set there.

Certainly some langpacks can be separated into additional subpackages to preserve disk space, but "by design" it remains the same -- the choice by env vars.

(To decrease possible startup performance issues, langpacks might be repackaged from ".xpi" file to plain dir, with chrome.manifest uncompressed and other stuff recompressed into a new .jar file).

Summary: Update elfhack code in SeaMonkey up to ESR68 level
Description:
Elfhack is used to optimize ELF shared binaries on Linux/UNIX systems.
It decreases libxul.so size up to 9Mb (10%) and speedups startup time.

The current code is still oriented on binaries produced by traditional gcc compiler (and bfd linker).
To support clang compiler and lld linker, as well as possible future needs for building with lto, elfhack should be updated.

The final code of ESR68 seems satisfy all possible needs for years to come.

Note, *build/unix/elfhack/\** is an isolated thing that does not correlate with anything else (ie. no prerequisites in general).
All the commits below can be quiet applied cleanly step by step.

Summary: Browser: Frequent short UI freezes on particular web pages
Description:
I'm experiencing frequent UI freezes with Seamonkey (if memory serves me right since ~ version 2.49), e.g. when loading a new website, entering an URL in the URL bar, while scrolling on a website or even multiple times while typing this text.

In all of those cases CPU usage increases to 100% on one CPU, stays that way for maybe 2 seconds, and the complete UI is frozen during that time (though events will be processed once it normalizes again). My impression is that this always happens when an opened website is using a lot of JavaScript.

Steps to reproduce:
===================

A good example is when visiting Kickstarter (even when doing so with a fresh profile):
* Visit https://www.kickstarter.com
* The Seamonkey logo in the upper right corner will freeze for about a second, together with the rest of the UI
* As soon as the site is loaded, click on one of the categories (e.g. "Games").
* This time, Seamonkey will freeze even longer

Older Seamonkey versions or the current Firefox version keep reacting during the whole time. My impression is that Seamonkey will be permanently slower even when closing the tab after that.

I'm not sure whether this is platform specific - it is happening for me both on my openSUSE and Slackware Linux PCs, but I don't have a Windows or Mac PC for comparison.

Summary: Accelerators to tag messages are not shown in the Message -> Tag menu
Description:
In the support newsgroup, it was pointed out that the accelerators which can be used to tag messages are not shown in the Message->Tag menu in SeaMonkey Mail&News, but do appear in Thunderbird[1].

This menu seems to be built in mailWindowOverlay.js, in SetMessageTagLabel(). While in SeaMonkey this function sets the accesskey attribute, in Thunderbird it sets both accesskey and acceltext. See bug 781466 and the related commit[2].

[1] news://news.mozilla.org/TOidnaeBsMBvc6LCnZ2dnUU7-VWdnZ2d@mozilla.org
[2] https://hg.mozilla.org/comm-central/rev/3b436975ce82

Summary: Unable to select folders/directories with the XUL file picker
Description:
In SeaMonkey 2.53.3 on GNU/Linux, with ui.allow_platform_file_picker set to false (so that the XUL file picker is used), I can't save two or more files at the same time.

There are at least two ways to reproduce this: in Mail&News by saving two or more attachments at once and in the Navigator Page Info dialog Media tab, also by saving two or more items at the same time.

This may have been introduced by bug 1335539, where the use of wrapDOMFile in nsFilePicker.js was replaced with createFromNsIFile[1]. This seems to fail silently when the file picker is used to choose a directory. Adding a catch() to these promises, I get NS_ERROR_FILE_IS_DIRECTORY.

If I'm understanding the code correctly, CreateFromNsIFile in dom/file/File.cpp calls FileCreatorHelper::CreateFile in FileCreatorHelper.cpp, which calls CreateFileInternal, which calls CreateBlobImpl. This last one calls InitializeChromeFile in MultipartBlobImpl.cpp, which will fail for directories (line 360 for 2.53.3 final).

[1] https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/diff/e769531b24333372cf6e28c6c495abb069136060/toolkit/components/filepicker/nsFilePicker.js

Expected results:

The video controls should work on all sites as Firefox, Chrome and MS Edge does.

Summary: add other language user interface

Summary: View Image error on canvas
Description:
Clicking "View Image" on a Canvas (which probably the same time is a frame) produces an error:
```
Error: TypeError: Argument 1 is not valid for any of the 1-argument overloads of URL.createObjectURL.
Source File: chrome://communicator/content/nsContextMenu.js
Line: 1127
```
The problem is
[let blobUrl = URL.createObjectURL(this.target);](https://gitlab.com/seamonkey-project/seamonkey-2.53-comm/-/blob/2_53_4_beta_01/suite/base/content/nsContextMenu.js#L1127)
because *this.target.toBlob()* must be used rather then just *this.target* .
(And *toBlob()* canvas method is async).

Note, the correspond Fx part has [toBlob()](https://gitlab.com/seamonkey-project/seamonkey-2.53-mozilla/-/blob/2_53_4_beta_01/browser/base/content/content.js#L879)

Preliminary patch attached (fixed the issue).

Summary: Memory leak and unresponsive
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.4

Steps to reproduce:

Does not matter. Problem seems to be related to memory usage.
Simply open 300-500 pictures in tabs.


Actual results:

1. Memory usage is increasing even when I do nothing.
Obviously a leak.

2. More important
When reaching 900 MB memory the browser gets more and more slow.
At 1000 MB it becomes absolutely unresponsive and needs to be killed.
Sometimes I have to do this 5 times a day.   :(





Expected results:

It just should work!
I don't understand why this has not been fixed for a long time.

I have tested Firefox 78.3 ESR  and  Pale Moon 28.14 in the same environment.
Both are working fine.

Summary: NEWS FEED subject lines are incorrectly displayed in a place where EMAIL subject lines are supposed to be displayed
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/85.0.4183.121 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce:

Create a News and Feeds account. Add some subscriptions.

Create a search folder called 'unread' of unread messages, i.e. searching on status not equal to read.

View the unread folder and type a search term into the search box to limit articles to those whose subject line contains the term.

Remove the search term by clicking on the sweeping brush icon.

Select the email Inbox.



Actual results:

After a pause, the News and Feed subjects from the unread folder are displayed in the place where Inbox email subjects should be displayed.


Expected results:

Email Inbox subjects should have been displayed.

This happens in 2.53.4 but has happened in previous, possibly for years.

Summary: Search messages from mail window does not work
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0

Steps to reproduce:

Open an e-mail in a separate window by double clicking on it.
Make sure the button "Search Messages" is present in the Tool bar.
Click the "Search Messages" button.



Actual results:

The search Window pops up, but there are no search options present in the search field and the "Search for messages in:" drop down box is not prefilled with the current e-mail folder.  Even after selecting a folder in the "Search for messages in:" drop down - there is still no search options available - so a search cannot be started.


Expected results:

The search Window should show the same as if  "Tools" -> "Search Messages" in the menu had been chosen, or if Ctrl+Shift+S had been pressed.

Summary: Website Navigation Bar: "rel is not defined" when rel has more than one value
Description:
In linkToolbarHandler.js, line 32 compares the value of rel, resulting (with the Website Navigation Bar visible) in "ReferenceError: rel is not defined" when this condition is evaluated.

This check was introduced in bug 240393, see [0]. Should it be "linkElement.relValues[i]" instead of "rel"?

[0] https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/attachment.cgi?id=300877&action=diff

Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.11; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.4

Steps to reproduce:

This bug happens frequently when I try to change the text-color of an already typed text, or background color, both in the HTML- Composer-page or writing or editing a new e-mail.


Actual results:

Instead of the normal color-menu, with the various little colors to choose from, I get a blank grey block of the same size, and the window freezes: I can no longer work on this document, not close it either. All other open windows do work, but I have to entirely shut down SeaMonkey, and therefore most often loose what new document I was working on. 


Expected results:

The menu for colors (text- or background) should have opened normally, like it did in the earlier versions. (2.49) and I should have been able to keep on working.

From 2.54.4:
I log on as usual. Mail is peridically checked from some time (2 hours?) and from then no checks anymore. EACH TIME that I press 'Get Msgs" I have to re-enter the POP password.

The mail should have been retrieved immediately

Summary: POP3 client of Yahoo email account does not work due to password security

Steps to reproduce:

I have an email account on Yahoo which supports access by POP3 clients such as SeaMonkey. I configured the account as specified by Yahoo in SeaMonkey. Then when I opened SeaMonkey email, it asked me for the password of the Yahoo account which I entered. 


Actual results:

 The password was taken in by SeaMonkey but did not read in any emails. In addition, within 20 seconds, I got this message from SeaMonkey 
"Sending of password for user kirk.anderson1 did not succeed. Mail server pop.mail.yahoo.com responded: Server error - Please try again later"


Expected results:

Emails should have been downloaded from Yahoo. And I did check that the password I entered was the same password that worked on Yahoo login

Summary: Seamonkey 2.53.5 could not successfully store self-signed certificates
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0

Steps to reproduce:

1. I have started mail/news.
2. I have clicked on an IMAP folder. The related server has a self-signed certificate unknown to Seamonkey.
3. Security dialog appears. It mentions authentication method is not correct (it is indeed correct). It asks for permanently storing the self-signed certificate.
4. I click to permanently store self-signed certificate.
5. Dialog disappears as if storage has been succeed, but IMAP connection cannot be established.
6. If checked at that stage, certificate store includes an [unknown] certificate seems like it has been stored. However, it cannot be exported or viewed, but could be deleted. After the deletion, issue remains if you start over from #1.
7. If you continue to repeat #1 to #6, the security dialog shown on #3 getting larger at each iteration and exceeds screen size.


Actual results:

The certificate could not be stored.


Expected results:

It should be stored and be effective during connections.

Summary: Preferences window cropped at the right side on open

User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.15; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.5.1

I installed Seamonkey  2.53.5 under Mac OS 10.15.7 (Catalina) and opened Preferences (I'm using the Modern Theme).

Preferences opens, but the Pane is presented to small for the content - horizontally.  If I cursor to the edge (to get a drag arrow) and double click the Pane opens fully.

This also happens with Seamonkey 2.53.5.1.


Expected results:

Preference Pane should be presented fully open when selected without having to stretch the Pane to the correct default size.

Summary: Constant intermitant hang ups while typing or scrolling.
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.5.1

Steps to reproduce:

I didn't have to do a thing.  The system is constantly hanging up while typing and scrolling.  The pointer stops moving, the the Windows busy icon comes up, and then after a few seconds it releases and you can start scrolling again.  When typing the flashing vertical line just freezes up and you can't see what you are typing until after it releases.  So far it has hung up three times just while I  have been typing this!


Actual results:

See above.


Expected results:

I should be able to type and scroll with NO interuptions, like I eas able to do up until a few months ago.  I have two desktops and one laptop.  One of the desktops is running Windows 7, the laptop and the other desktop are on Windows 10 and all three have the exact same problem!  The laptop and Windows 7 desktop both have had a clean install of Windows in the past four months.  Also the Microsoft Edge web browser DOES NOT have this problem so it is NOT a Windows problem, but a Seamonkey problem.  I can't believe that I am the only person having this problem.

Summary: password retention
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.5.1

Steps to reproduce:

[Environment:]
Windows 10 Pro
SeaMonkey 2.53.5.1 - 20201115161931

As a way of ensuring that I don't forget my account passwords, I do not let the password manager save my password for POP and IMAP connections, so that I have to enter passwords on first connection to servers.  The expectation is for entering passwords once per session. (I do allow saving for SMTP and LDAP connections, so that I don't have to enter each time I touch the server for those functions.)






Actual results:

Since upgrade to 2.53.4, Seamonkey seems to be forgetting session passwords.  Over the course of a workday, clicking on "Get Msgs" for an account without a password saved in the password manager causes a prompt for a password.  This is happening with multiple accounts on different services (and different mail server software).  


Expected results:

Keep entered passwords for POP and IMAP connections cached until the end of the session.  

I am not seeing similar behavior in any versions of Thunderbird.

Summary: Provide complete and correct instructions for fetching and building source
Description:
I package SeaMonkey for openSUSE but as of 2.53.6b1 my usual checkout + build process is no longer working due to the removal of `client.mk` from the base directory.  I'm trying to figure out the current correct way of fetching the source from version control and building it, but the documentation for this seems to be scattered, contradictory, incorrect, and incomplete.  It would be helpful if a complete and correct version of the instructions could be put in *one* place.  I'll try to provide an overview of the interrelated problems with the documentation, but please excuse me if this gets a bit hairy.

Let's start at the [README](https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/seamonkey/releases/2.53.6b1/README.txt), because this directly linked from [the release page](https://www.seamonkey-project.org/releases/2.53.6b1) with the description "The README file explains how to pull SeaMonkey 2.53.6 Beta 1 from the source repository."

The very beginning of the README gives the following instructions for checking out the sources from version control:

> These binaries were all built from SeaMonkey's 2.53 GitLab repositories, off
> the 2_53_6_beta_01 branch, and Mozilla's repositories for the extensions, off the
> default branch, with the following commands used to obtain the sources:
> 
>    git clone -b 2_53_6_beta_01 https://gitlab.com/seamonkey-project/seamonkey-2.53-comm.git comm-253
>    cd comm-253
>    git clone -b 2_53_6_beta_01 https://gitlab.com/seamonkey-project/seamonkey-2.53-mozilla.git mozilla
>    cd mozilla/extensions
>    hg clone https://hg.mozilla.org/chatzilla irc
>    hg clone https://hg.mozilla.org/dom-inspector inspector

These commands work fine, insofar as they don't result in any errors.  However, the README goes on to say that

> A source code tarball with the contents of all the repositories, ready to
> build, is available for download from the source/ subdirectory here on FTP.

There are a couple problems with this statement:

1. It refers to getting files by FTP, but all the download links on the release page are to an HTTP server.  Maybe an official FTP server still exists somewhere, but if so, it doesn't seem to be the preferred way of downloading the tarball any more, and in any case these instructions don't help users who are looking for the tarball on the web server instead.  Rather than writing "here on FTP", it would be better to provide the exact URL(s) of the source/ subdirectory.  In the case of 2.53.6b1, this is presumably <https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/seamonkey/releases/2.53.6b1/source/> for the tarball hosted on the web server.

2. The tarball hosted on the web server has a different directory structure than the one produced with the instructions at the beginning of the README.  As far as I can tell, it was produced by first checking out the seamonkey-2.53-mozilla repository and then checking out the seamonkey-2.53-comm repository in a subdirectory, rather than the other way around.  If this is the correct way of doing things now, then the instructions in the README need to be updated.  If it's not the correct way of doing things, then the source tarball needs to be restructured.  If both ways are correct, then the README needs to mention this (and to explain why it chose to provide instructions that result in a source tree that differs so conspicuously from the official source tarball).

The README goes on with the following instructions for building SeaMonkey:

> Read https://www.seamonkey-project.org/dev/ for instructions on how to build
> your own copy of SeaMonkey.

This statement is problematic because that page contains no instructions at all for building SeaMonkey. The closest hint it provides is to to check the Mozilla developer guide:

> Even though we are independent from [Mozilla](http://www.mozilla.org/), as we're based on the same framework as Firefox, most of the [mozilla.org developer pages](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Developer_guide) also apply to SeaMonkey, there's also content there that explains [how to get the comm-central source code](https://developer.mozilla.org/En/Developer_Guide/Source_Code/Getting_comm-central), which includes the current SeaMonkey development code.

Unfortunately, the link titled "how to get the comm-central source code" goes to a nonexistent page.  The previous link, "mozilla.org developer pages", is a bit more useful as it leads to a page with a [Build Instructions](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Developer_Guide/Build_Instructions) link described as "How to build Firefox, Thunderbird, SeaMonkey, or other Mozilla applications."  That page in turn links to a [Simple Seamonkey build](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Developer_guide/Build_Instructions/Simple_SeaMonkey_build) page that purports to contain instructions for checking out the source, creating a basic `.mozconfig` file, and building the application.  But there are two problems with these instructions:

1. The instructions for checking out the source are completely different from those contained in the SeaMonkey README.  Following these instructions results in yet another source tree, different from both the one you get from following the README instructions and the one from the official source tarball.  Perhaps this is because the instructions on MDN are for checking out the master branch rather than the branch/tag for a particular version of SeaMonkey, but even if so, this doesn't help people who came to these instructions from the README.

2. The instructions don't actually work; they say to run `python client.py checkout` but the repository doesn't contain any `client.py` file in the base directory.  (See [mdn/content Issue 725](https://github.com/mdn/content/issues/725).)

In summary, it would be helpful if the following could be fixed:

1. The instructions for checking out the source code given in the README should result in a source tree that bears at least a passing resemblance to the one you get from the official source tarball.

2. The instructions in the README should be more specific about where to obtain the source tarballs (code, l10n, language packs) rather than just saying "here on FTP".

3. The instructions in the README and at https://www.seamonkey-project.org/dev/ should refer to a page that contains complete and correct build instructions.

4. If said build instructions are supposed to live at the [Simple Seamonkey build](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Developer_guide/Build_Instructions/Simple_SeaMonkey_build) on MDN, then those instructions should be modified so that (a) the source checkout instructions are correct, and (b) the build instructions are comprehensible and correct for someone who checked out the source for a particular version of SeaMonkey using the the very different method specified in the SeaMonkey README.

Summary: Newsgroup Subscribe dialog incorrectly themed
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.6

Steps to reproduce:

Using SeaMonkey v. 2.53.6 beta 1
1. Enable the SeaMonkey Modern Theme.
2. In Messenger click on the name of a newsgroup. 
3. Click on "Manage newsgroup subscriptions".
4. You will se both square checkboxes and dot/checkmarks.
5. There will also be checboxes for non-subscribable items ("folders").

6. Also the column header "Subscribe" and the column selector is no longer present in v. 2.53.6 beta 1



Actual results:

7. Write something in the field "Show items that contain:"
8. Now only square checkboxes are shown (as expected).

9.  Select an item - the square checkboxes does not change to selected state
This part works in my PinBall theme though ( https://madsenworld.dk/pinball/pinball@pinball.madsenworld.dk.xpi ).


Expected results:

When the theme uses customized (square) checkboxes, then the dots and checkmarks should not be shown as well.

It comes doewn to the messenger\subscribe.css file:
-------------------------
treechildren::-moz-tree-image(subscribedColumn),
treechildren::-moz-tree-image(subscribedColumn2) {
  list-style-image: url("chrome://global/skin/checkbox/cbox.gif");
}

treechildren::-moz-tree-image(subscribedColumn, subscribed-true),
treechildren::-moz-tree-image(subscribedColumn2, subscribed-true) {
  list-style-image: url("chrome://global/skin/checkbox/cbox-check.gif");
}

treechildren::-moz-tree-image(subscribedColumn, subscribable-false) {
  list-style-image: none;
}
-------------------------

where styling of treechildren::-moz-tree-image(subscribedColumn) doesn't work correctly, leaving the hardcoded selection items visible next to the themed selection items.

Summary: Scratchpad "Pretty Print" doesn't understand template literals
Description:
The following JS statement prints `Hello world` to the console with a trivial use of a template literal:
```
console.log(`Hello ${"world"}`); 
```
With this statement in the Scratchpad (Shift+F4), select "Pretty Print":
```/*
Exception: Error while performing task "pretty-print": Error: Unexpected character '`' (1:12)
[4]</pp.raise@resource://devtools/shared/acorn/acorn.js:940:13
[13]</pp.getTokenFromCode@resource://devtools/shared/acorn/acorn.js:2785:3
[13]</pp.readToken@resource://devtools/shared/acorn/acorn.js:2490:10
[13]</pp.nextToken@resource://devtools/shared/acorn/acorn.js:2482:66
[13]</pp.next@resource://devtools/shared/acorn/acorn.js:2431:3
[13]</pp.getToken@resource://devtools/shared/acorn/acorn.js:2435:3
prettyFast@resource://devtools/shared/pretty-fast/pretty-fast.js:778:15
@resource://devtools/server/actors/pretty-print-worker.js:41:24
createHandler/<@resource://devtools/shared/worker/helper.js:85:24

@resource://devtools/server/actors/pretty-print-worker.js:51:12
createHandler/<@resource://devtools/shared/worker/helper.js:85:24

*/```
The test statement can however be run from the Scratchpad.

Obviously this isn't satisfactory.

I don't know whether it affects other code branches with Scratchpad (eg, incomplete implementation of bug 1317375), or it's specific to SeaMonkey, or it's just an issue from porting to SeaMonkey. It was probably present in 2.49.x. Apparently (bug 1565380) Scratchpad is no longer shipped in FireFox, and and I don't have a relevant old version to hand for testing.

Summary: Undefined reference when adding an image in composer.
Description:
If you add an image in the composer window and leave the image dialog with ok an undefined reference error for gMsgCompInputElement will be shown in the log for mailnews/compose/content/mailComposeEditorOverlay.xul. gMsgCompInputElement is not initialized in a composer window only in an image dialog created from the mailnews compose window.

moz-do-not-send seems not to be set as a result but this seems to be mostly harmless. Becuase I am unable to test uploading right now I am unsure if it has other implications but not a new error.

For comm-central the code is now in https://searchfox.org/comm-central/source/suite/editor/components/dialogs/content/EdImageLinkLoader.js#54

Summary: Broken bug link in 2.53.6 release notes
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 SeaMonkey/2.53.5.1

Steps to reproduce:

On the release notes for SeaMonkey 2.53.6 at <https://www.seamonkey-project.org/releases/seamonkey2.53.6/>, under "Known Issues", there is a link to bug 1684651 (text "The scrollbar is not always visible on some websites under recent macOS versions (10.15 upwards) see bug 1684651.")

The href attribute on the "bug 1684651" anchor is missing the opening quote, leading to the closing quote being interpreted as part of the URL and giving a broken link to <https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1684651%22>. Fairly minor and easy enough to work around by removing "%22" (displayed as a quote in the address bar) for those who realise what's happened, but I figured it'd probably be good to correct for future releases if that issue is likely to still need to be mentioned.


Actual results:

"bug 1684651" link opened <https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1684651%22>


Expected results:

"bug 1684651" link should open <https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1684651>

Summary: Missing features in SeaMonkey 2.53 and 2.57 newsgroup Subscribe dialog
Description:
+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #1685551 +++

rdf code in the subscribe dialog was removed in Bug 1425962. Currently SeaMonkey and Thunderbird share the same code. Unfortunately some of the previous features are now missing after the update.

- The subscribe tree opens up fully unfolded which it didn't before.
- The column header "Subscribe" and the column selector is no longer present.
- Sorting is not possible.

We should try to bring at least some of the features back.

Summary: Replace helpviewer for SeaMonkey 2.57
Description:
The help viewer is broken in SeaMonkey 2.57 because of RDF removals. It needs to be rewritten. 

Ideas are for an html based viewer windows able to either display a local copy or remote website content.

Summary: Rewrite sidebar for SeaMonkey 2.57
Description: The sidebar is broken in SeaMonkey 2.57 because of RDF removals. RDF usage needs to be removed.

Summary: File->Offline->Download/Sync Now and clicking on "Select" item in SeaMonkey does not work

Bug 464710 caused a regression.
File->Offline->Download/Sync Now and clicking on "Select" item iwill show a broken subscribe dialog and you need to either close the window or kill SeaMonkey on Windows via the task manager to close the mail window.

Error console shows:

Timestamp: 2/6/2021, 5:13:29 PM
Error: ReferenceError: ftvItem is not defined
Source File: chrome://messenger/content/msgSelectOfflineFolders.js
Line: 10

Our current folderpane.js is missing the implementation of ftvItem.

Affected versions 2.53.5b1 to 2.53.6

Summary: Support mozbuild 3.3 in SeaMonkey
Description:
Currently if you try to compile under Windows with mozbuild 3.3 the l10 packager will fail and the Lightning add-on will have an invalid id in its en-US install.rdf. This is mostly a 2.53 and 2.57 bug affecting makefiles but some of this is still in comm-central.
Cause is that defines in Makefiles used for the python preprocessor with double quotes and curly brackets are not expanded correctly. This isn't a problem for other mozilla based products because there are no similar cases left in Gecko code. Ours will go away later but need to be fixed in the interim.

Summary: Further clean up SeaMonkey 2.53 and 2.57 source repos
Description:
Our copies contain a bunch of unwanted stuff which is in the way for backporting.
Mostly in browser. While it does not directly affect us we should get rid of it to not try to backport stuff only needed for these parts.

Summary: Handling of mis-entered password
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.6

Steps to reproduce:

When I enter a POP/IMAP password incorrectly, a subsequent re-enter of a correct password also fails.  The only way around this is to cancel the connection, then click Get Msgs, and then re-enter the correct password.



Expected results:

Transmit the re-entered password following the prompt (and not having to cancel the exchange).  I believe that without the cancel, the re-entered password is being ignored, and the original mis-entered password is being resent.  This is happening with both POP and IMAP connections.

This one seems not to be a universal problem.  I've not seen an issue when connecting to servers running Zimbra or Exchange, but I have seen it with Fastmail (which I've discovered runs Cyrus IMAP), and I believe I saw the same issue on another server that I used to use that was also Cyrus IMAP.

I'm inclined to suggest that this might be something that is specific to Cyrus IMAP.

Summary: Cannot connect to imap server using OAuth2 authentication method
Description: My university uses Microsoft 365 accounts for email, and they have recently enabled two-factor authentication, which requires OAuth2 as a login method. When I setup my account in Thunderbird, there are no issues. I am brought to the login window for the Microsoft account and I can log in. When I try to setup the new authentication method in SeaMonkey, however, I receive an error message that the server doesn't support the specified authentication method, which is clearly not true since it works with Thunderbird. I have also tried to create a fresh profile to verify that there wasn't a problem with the one I usually use, but the error persists.

Summary: Change cZ gif statusbar and menu icons to png and remove 16x10 icon.
Description:
buc tracked down a possible performance problem with to 16x.10 gif icon. Gif icons will be replaced overtime with later formats so let take the opportunity to do this here first for the statusbar and menu bar icon.
The status bar icon also is 16x10 and can just be the same as the 16x16 menu bar icon.

Trivial fix so can go into 2.53.7 final release.

+++ snip +++

A broken choice of chatzilla's taskbar icon leads to a constant redrawing of the screen.

Disable ALL the extensions (chatzilla, inspector, lightning) in about:addons, and run SeaMonkey from cmdline with debug:

MOZ_LOG="nsRefreshDriver:5" seamonkey

The debug output stopped after the page is completed, until you move mouse etc., then it stopped again etc.etc It is an expected behaviour.

Then enable chatzilla in about:addons and repeat the MOZ_LOG run.

After the page is completed, the debug output still present infinitely, despite you do nothing.

The problem is suite/extensions/irc/xul/skin/images/taskbar-irc.gif icon, with size 16x10 .
It seems the code require geometry of 16x16 in this area. If you try to use png or jpg icon with another size there, it just not appear. But in the case of gif, the icon with the size of 16x10 (instead of 16x16) still appear, with a side effect of permanent refreshing of the screen (according to the debug output).

Linux: Handling of dead keys in text input fields broken since GTK 3.24.26
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.8

Steps to reproduce:

GTK 3.24.26 was released a month ago and introduced a new way of handling dead keys. Usually, pressing ` does not show anything and only after pressing e one sees √®. Starting with that GTK version, ` is already displayed, accompanied by a "short _" below the accent, and pressing e afterwards yields √®.  A visualisation can be seen in this blogpost: https://blog.gtk.org/2021/03/24/input-revisited/




Actual results:

Trying to type √® (or any other letters in combination with dead keys) in any text field in SeaMonkey (URL bar, new mail, this bug submission form, ...) yields √®`. Namely, the accent is printed twice, once on the letter and once after it.


Expected results:

The input text should read √®.

I observed this issue with both the latest version from WG9s (that uses bundled libraries) as well as with my self-build version on Arch Linux (that uses system libraries). A test downgrade to GTK 3.24.25 restored the functionality.

I also tested it with previous official versions: Dead keys work as expected up to version 2.53.4 but are broken starting with 2.53.5b1.

This issue does not occur with neither the current Firefox nor with the latest Waterfox Classic 56.5 (waterfox-classic-2021.02.en-US.linux-x86.tar.bz2).

Summary: SeaMonkey ignores Ubuntu's large text mode
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.7

Steps to reproduce:

1. Launch a fresh SeaMonkey profile.

2. Open Ubuntu (20.04) settings and choose "Universal Access".

3. Toggle Large Text mode on/off.


Actual results:

Text on webpages displayed in SeaMonkey, and in SeaMonkey browser chrome, remained the same size. As you can see in the attached screenshots, only the browser titlebar scales up.


Expected results:

Text should scale up.

This is SeaMonkey 2.53.7, downloaded directly from seamonkey-project.org.

Summary: SeaMonkey 2.53.7 broke mouse wheel tab switching
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0

Steps to reproduce:

Up to SeaMonkey 2.53.6, I was using Tab Wheel Scroll extension: https://addons.thunderbird.net/pl/seamonkey/addon/tab-wheel-scroll/

This way, scrolling the mouse on the tab bar itself acted as previous/next tab switching control.


Actual results:

Upgraded to SeaMonkey 2.53.7. Scrolling doesn't work. After filling the tab bar with more tabs (so it overfills and gets scroll buttons), I've noticed scroll wheel now acts as scrolling of the bar itself.  The Tab Wheel Scroll extension doesn't work.

HOWEVER! There is a single pixel line just above the tab bar where mouse wheel scrolling actually works and switches the active tab. It's invisible, but it's there. Also, scrolling the wheel above the "new tab" or "close tab" buttons does what it's supposed to, even with the extension disabled.

The about:config setting "browser.tabs.mouseScrollAdvancesTab" (default: true) doesn't do what it's supposed to (and never did according to bug #1416737). HOWEVER, it does do something - when scrolling on the invisible line, it switches by TWO tabs instead of one when the setting is disabled (set to false).


Expected results:

Optimally, browser.tabs.mouseScrollAdvancesTab should behave like I expect (which it did since Netscape times, and apparently until SeaMonkey 2.40). Scrolling on the tabs themselves should switch active tab. Setting to off should bring the current behavior back.

I would leave the setting ON by default, arguing that Chrome does the same on Linux, although it can be off just like FireFox. For FireFox, this setting is also off by default, but can be enabled with the setting "toolkit.tabbox.switchByScrolling".

Alternatively, I would happily keep using the above mentioned extension, but something in SM 2.53.7 broke it.

Summary: Update available IRC networks
Description:
Some IRC networks no longer seem to exist:
* serenia
* solidirc

Some have changed their server addresses:
* ircnet
* efnet

Others have additional server addresses:
* dalnet
* undernet
* quakenet

Also added servers for those that accept secure connections on port 6697

Summary: Deal with /server and /sslserver better
Description:
If the port is not specified with /server and /sslserver then it is currently assumed to be the default so 6667 and 6697 whereas we should check the network / server list and use the port from that list if it exists then otherwise use the defaults.
The updated code also removes some duplication in the command callers.

Steps to reproduce:

I upgraded the Seamonkey suit from 2.53.4 to the latest 2.53.7 (Lightning integrated)

User agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.7
Build identifier: 20210327145208

I lost the previews of the calendar invitations in the mail view. (They can only be seen in the Print Preview of the mail.)

Summary: View Mail does not have option to show/block remote images
Description:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:60.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/60.0 SeaMonkey/2.53.7

Steps to reproduce:

I have "Block images and other content" set in options.  I tried unchecking that option, and it still blocked Remote Content for eMail.



Actual results:

Unchecking "Block images and other content" had no effect.  Remote content still blocked.

Unchecking "Block images and other content" should have allowed remote content, ei: Images, etc to be displayed.

Summary: SeaMonkey crashed a couple of times when I launched it
Description:
I downloaded a standalone version of SeaMonkey 2.57 and it crashed a couple of times when I launched it.
When I went into preferences, my screen reader on my PC told me that preferences is not responding.

Summary: problem with the email end of SeaMonkey
Description:
I setup my AOL account with SeaMonkey, and it was working perfectly, however, when I went to setup my verizon email account, I configured my pop3 server settings, however, it wouldn't allow me to type in my password, whatsoever,
so I removed my account, and readded it, and I ran into the same problem.
And AOL took over the verizon email service.
Now when adding my AOL account, I was able to type in my password, and also, I experienced unexpected behavior with SeaMonkey 2.57 as well, when using a screen reader, such as jaws and NVDA, when your in the compose edit box, where you type in your email address, jaws acts like it's autofilling it in, by trying to repeat a word, in stead of one letter, at a time, now I unchecked the checkbox, that says add outgoing email addresses, to my collected addresses, and I can still, reproduce this problem, it didn't do it earlier.

Summary: Memory leak and stalling when surfing to corona figures at github
Description:
Seamonkey had memory leaks, that is an issue for months, but this breaks everything. when surfing to https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer to get the latest spreadsheet with all the world in coronadata, and clicking on the link covid-19 dataset (left, top) Seamonkey memory usage explodes and Seamonkey and my computer freezes. Only way to leave this is a hard reset with the on/off button.
Firefox and Opera are handling the link alright and present the Github-directory with the required spreadsheet. 
Please fix this!

Summary: Website wrongly claims that source tarball doesn't unpack into its own directory
Description:
The releases page at https://www.seamonkey-project.org/releases/#source lists the two source tarballs as follows:

> * Source Code Tarball (xz, 270 MB) - note that it doesn't unpack a subdirectory itself, so create a directory to unpack it in.
> * Source Localisation Tarball (xz, 12 MB) - note that it doesn't unpack a subdirectory itself, so create a directory to unpack it in. 

The note about the tarball not unpacking into a subdirectory is correct for the localization tarball, but not for the main source code tarball (which, at least as of 2.53.7.1, unpacks into a subdirectory named seamonkey-2.53.7.1).  The note should be deleted from the first bullet point.

Summary: Wrong links and other inconsistencies on Community page
Description:
Steps how to reproduce:

1. Visit Community page on projectwebsite
2. Below heading "mozilla.support.seamonkey" try Mailing List: support-seamonkey@lists.mozilla.org [subscribe/unsubscribe](https://lists.mozilla.org/listinfo/support-seamonkey)
3. Below heading "mozilla.dev.apps.seamonkey" try Mailing List: dev-apps-seamonkey@lists.mozilla.org [subscribe/unsubscribe](https://lists.mozilla.org/listinfo/dev-apps-seamonkey)

   ¬ª Expected: for (2), (3): mailing list handling page open  
       actual: Error 404 üò•

4. below **Add-Ons for SeaMonkey** link to mozdev should lead to [mozdev.org](http://www.mozdev.org/projects/applications/SeaMonkey.html)  
       actual: Error 404 üò•  
5.  [Modified Firefox Extensions](http://xsidebar.mozdev.org/modifiedmisc.htmlhttp://xsidebar.mozdev.org/modifiedmisc.html) should lead to extensions  
       actual: "address  not found" üò•  


### Additional information
Mailing list links need to be switched to new group handling pages [dev-apps-seamonkey](https://groups.google.com/a/lists.mozilla.org/g/dev-apps-seamonkey/ "dev-apps-seamonkey@lists.mozilla.org") and [support-seamonkey](https://groups.google.com/a/lists.mozilla.org/g/support-seamonkey/ "support-seamonkey")

### Additional inconsistencies
#### Newsgroups / Mailing Lists  
a) I doubt that the linked NewsGroups still are active. But may be Download of the old contents / postings still is possible with a newsreader? I don'tknow.
a1) The google mirrors of the NewsGroups still are useful, but it should be mentioned that the groups are **outdated** (deprecated? should no longer be used?).
